body_html:
Performance comparison

For a particular (N, C, IH, IW, H, W) tuple, I generated random input and grid tensors and called forward and backward.

In general, for small values of (N, C, IH, IW, H, W) (everything less than ~20), the THCUNN is
faster than the CUDNN version.

For larger sizes, the CUDNN version is roughly 2x faster.

Script: https://gist.github.com/zou3519/8e4ce6652a3dd132a8c4336e697bbbf0
Results: https://gist.github.com/zou3519/6de82f81438de1ea136658b9e9b2ced3

body:
## Performance comparison
For a particular (N, C, IH, IW, H, W) tuple, I generated random input and grid tensors and called forward and backward.

In general, for small values of (N, C, IH, IW, H, W) (everything less than ~20), the THCUNN is
faster than the CUDNN version.

For larger sizes, the CUDNN version is roughly 2x faster.

Script: https://gist.github.com/zou3519/8e4ce6652a3dd132a8c4336e697bbbf0
Results: https://gist.github.com/zou3519/6de82f81438de1ea136658b9e9b2ced3
